ljTSpiQnPYtVX_xzS41YUg.text: Excellent ramen! Best pork belly I've had in any ramen in a long time.   The only thing I didn't like about the place was the metal water cups.

esskMmAniBkNKB3gIMD0PA.text: Best authentic Ramen in Phoenix hands down. If you aren't used to authentic Ramen though I caution you. Flavors are strong and most of the broths are very rich and fatty. Start off with a chicken broth if you are not used to truly authentic ramen. Or get the black garlic pork ramen and clear your calendar the next day. Your digestive system will be throwing a party! Such great flavor and depth. Amazing.

93B1tP7wfGy3xCRRuKoTEA.text: I've been here one other time before during lunch time and service was great, quick wait times and food was pretty good. Came here on a Tuesday night with a party of 4 around 5pm (when they open) and had to wait until 6pm to get a table. Waited another hour to receive food. The food this time around was subpar at best. My ramen seemed like it was missing half the ingredients stated on the menu. Honestly, this is probably the most decent ramen place (when service is good) around the area. But with these wait times, it probably would have been more worth it to drive down to Tempe for ramen. If I were to come here again, I would go during lunch time.

JFHTS_zQfbWJX0G16NeDJQ.text: First I told her for my spicy tuna bowl give me 3 extra pieces of sea weed , came back with one then I told her to go get me 2 more I can here in the back the cook being a cheap ass complaining  Then they bring my order of spicy miso it was good asked bout my extra pork chashu said it's bigger pieces when the day before they looked the same and gave me extra on the side then I said like 4 times extra garlic oil not the black one and as I poured it whoopty fucken do it's the black one smh . Every time was good, real tasty food maybe just come at night different service, food good service horrible .

sR-cGlxnHk4nrjh6BbCm9g.text: We were sad after noodle bar closed. That was one of our favorite ramen places. Nishikawa has filled the hole that noodle bar has left behind. I had the Nishikawa Ramen bowl spicy and my friend had spicy miso. They were both absolutely delicious. Some of the best Ramen I've had in the valley.

IAh8xTGH5veMVsajhVwpmQ.text: We just can't find anything about Nishikawa to speak bad about. This place is rockin' the noodles

skVpNr_wrhSg1ub8R8v13Q.text: The ramen here is pretty good and probably the best we've had here in the valley.   Unfortunately, what I witnessed with one of the workers may have possibly been a health code violation. She was refilling the water bottles that each table gets. As she was refilling, she dropped the top on the floor, and put it back on the bottle to be served to patrons. She also used her bare hands to guide ice into the bottles and in the midst of this activity, went to go get some paper for the receipt roll and then preceded to go back to touching the ice without washing her hands. I also noticed the ice scoop resides inside the container for ice, with the handle and all.   The employees could use some FDA food code trainings. I don't know what else is being done in the back where there is no one to witness any violations.

QlgCRP1Rm7skj76bguOIlw.text: I've been to many Ramen places around the US and a few around the world. This place is as good as or better than most of them. It is the real deal.   Let's start with the service. They give you a giant pitcher of water to start. Awesome, I get thirsty. The waitress was amazing and friendly. She answered all my questions and then some. The place was small but very clean and nice. I drove 45 minutes from the West and it was worth every minute on I 10.  Now onto the food. I ordered some special ramen bowl and I was not disappointed. The broth was so good and savory. The first sip could quench an eternal thirst. It was fatty, yet clean. Deep and rich. Perfect amount of umami. The straighy noodles are made in house daily and i tasted the freshness. They are not too thick or too thin. The Perfect balance. They soaked up all that great broth. After finishing my first amount of noodles, I ordered more noodles. So freaking delicious. Next, the egg was on point. I ordered it soft boiled and you should too. Your a Neanderthal if you want it hardboiled. The softboiled egg was perfectly cooked. Gooey in the middle and bouncy on the outside. Lastly, but definitely not least, the chasu was heavenly. It was thick and included a large portion. It had a smokey flavor that melted in your mouth. No literally, it melted in my mouth. Even though the portion was generous, I wanted more but my stomach couldn't so it.  I ate my fill and then some. My buddy who is like 5'6 ate two full bowls. We went into a food coma. I need to go there again.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. So freaking good

9nOfBmw3arqGN-K2kLczQw.text: Pretty good ramen overall. I Would like to see more pork serving and different chili powder, but service was quick and friendly. Ambience is chill and space could he limited during a busy time. But i came on late afternoon sunday so it was nice.

GMCKHZ0KzqcI_gkyRWgr6Q.text: Food was really good. Super packed. It took an hour to get seated but food was worth it. Parking is alright. Wish they would make their place bigger because there are too many people waiting to eat.

xrHsTgU5F_Sy3r8PpXO7iw.text: Awesome ramen in generous portions. Not a great place to bring kids and a very small menu but it's great for ramen lovers seeking a good bowl of ramen in Phoenix.

VQCkDmTHg0mntxYyd7TFSQ.text: Amazing food! I fell in love with ramen only after this place. I have never had so many amazing flavors in my mouth at one time! The pork pieces were nice and juicy. They were generous with their pork too. Perfection.  Great service too. Overall a nice little simple place with just brilliant food!

SwrvXKs9QSym8x4cTsRTIw.text: Ordered the Nishikawa Ramen and it was delicious! Very spicy and flavorful. Service was prompt but I got the impression the waitress was a little impatient. A large group for a birthday party came in and it felt as if the staff was trying to get us to leave to accommodate them but we weren't even have done with our food. Overall a nice place with cute little anime toys at each table.

nx7yUbqb3KEak8lkb63Blg.text: Amazing!  Been many times and never disappoints. Flavors are wonderful, generous sized portions. Reasonably priced, quick service, and friendly.  Only "complaint" is small location means perpetual wait, but totally worth it!!!

cSHEA23auYrbrgU0QWrWKw.text: Very good got the pork belly ramen curry ramen and it wa s quite tasty.  Good service was well.

JT1nSsrsbugh1tKuQFdWpA.text: Definitely the best ramen I've had in Phoenix. A few quibbles, but the food is definitely good and satisfying. We arrived at around 1 on a Friday and it was quite busy, we had to wait a few minutes for a table.   I actually ordered the salmon roe rice bowl rather than ramen for my first meal. You can guess from the price (just over $5) that it's not going to be huge. But it's far enough from a full entree that I thought that should have been mentioned in the menu, which it was not. The bowl it's served in is tiny, basically overflowing with food. Which means when you start to eat it, it makes a mess. Food can't help but spill over the edges, because there's no room to spare in the bowl. It's a little like when you're served a martini in a glass that's so full you can't safely lift it to your mouth to drink it. Still, I enjoyed the combination of ingredients and it was satisfying.   My wife had been once before and got the tonkotsu ramen, which she said was very good, though still not competing with the better places we've been in NYC. Today she got the curry ramen, medium spicy, and was very pleased. She has a decent tolerance for spice, and was glad she didn't go beyond medium. That bowl had kick.   We shared pork gyoza to start. The crust on the wrapper was very pleasing, though the filling was a bit bland to my taste, and the ice cold dipping sauce detracted a bit from the enjoyment.   One odd service note. We both ordered green tea. It didn't arrive at the table until well after our main courses were served. Hard to understand why. It was just a little teapot with a bag of green tea, not some big elaborate production. Even by the end of the meal, the tea was so weak it barely tasted like tea at all. Left with most of the tea undrunk in the pots. Other than that, service was pretty good. I'll try some more of the menu. I wish we had better options, but for now this one will do.

dYIjwbVqaUBkkwmeb3ijXw.text: Awesome Ramen, I've been here several times and never disappointed. This is my hi to place for ramen in midtown can't miss.

_CNFDgiERUH7gwGyQXa_pQ.text: Two words... hidden gem!!! This is my new go to ramen spot. Such a great spot when your craving something comforting on a cold day but I will also come here when it's 115 out.. cause it's that GOOD!!! They give you plenty of food so no matter what you order you will be full and satisfied.

Gc-Qg6d582hsJkl22IunyQ.text: This place offers a taste of Japan in the desert.  The Shio Ramen is hands down my favorite. I usually order the Shio at a medium spice level because the natural favors are so good. The seasoned boiled eggs are the best. They also have delicious fun-fare such as Takoyaki (sweet batter with octopus inside) and fried squid. Be sure to wash down all the goodness with a cream melon soda- straight from Japan as well. This place does get busy so try to go right at 5pm to avoid the rush.

e_d7tPRnjKbmwJ34fwMH4A.text: The food is good, the servers are not very nice. We ordered the salmon roe bowl, which i had no idea were salmon eggs, and yes i realize that ordering the wrong item was our fault. But as soon as we saw the eggs we asked if we could switch the bowl to a pork bowl instead. The server didn't say anything and just said sure and didn't take the salmon egg bowl back. She then brings out the check and charged us for both. I asked a different server if we could take it off because we had obviously not touched the salmon bowl, and she said since we didn't send it back to the kitchen we were going to be charged. I feel like when i say "oh i didn't know it was salmon eggs and immediately ask for a pork bowl it implies that we were not going to eat it. After arguing with the server that we had never even touched the food she charged us for she just took the check and walked away. She gave us the check and eventually took the salmon off, but at this point was not talking to us at all. I honestly felt i asked very nicely to switch out the bowl and was very apologetic the entire time. And it seems like we just got sass in response and then had to argue further to get the food taken off. Food was good, service was terrible. Ruined the experience and will not be returning. Since when do restaurants not take back food that you don't like? Well this one doesn't so if you order something don't expect to send it back for a refund.

wBvu0fIisx3rrD_iQH2iTg.text: Excellent ramen and great value.   The broth was very favorable and not overly salty.  Very fresh ingredients and the service was fast.    I highly recommend the takoyaki appetizer. It is octopus covered in a fried batter. It is served hot so give it a moment to cool down before diving in.

_RPtpz-EhwzCloBwyUCgNA.text: Great food. I came here many times. If you looking for Japanese noodle soup I would like to recommend everyone come here.

3PfBBa-RPxPhZai13Em6xg.text: Great that AZ has ramen,,,unfortunate that it still has a long way to go for some decent ramen spots to open up. This place was no exception and fell in line with below average even for Az standard IMO, because AZ has no established competition YET. I think the "fusion" component to their cooking translates to "we use MSG" because their chashyu was laced with it...possibly the broth too which was very thin and lacked the layers of flavor and texture you get with decent Tonkotsu broth.  The only reason I gave them one star was because their "curly noodle" was their saving grace & they apparently make their noodles fresh-which I can appreciate. The chicken karaage was abnormally overcooked with a strange flavor-and upon mentioning it to the waitress, she explained they tend to over cook them since they have had complaints in the past of chicken being undercooked-so they want to make sure they are DONE. I can appreciate that, but if you really know how to do it right...it's possible to make chicken karaage juicy, crisp and golden. Not black/brown and tough.  I guess being 1/2 Japanese living in LA with so many options that are pretty damn close to authentic Ramen has spoiled me. I wish this place luck and hope they survive, if anything..to give other prospective "players" a chance to consider to open a kick ass place in Az because ramen does have popularity here.   This place is at least better than a poke in the eye on a chilly Arizona winter night.   Oh-and another note-on their website, they say: Nishikawa Ramen "Here is where we were granted the opporitunity of learning from a master of ramen. Through him we were taught the art of a creamy broth, the beauty of a perfect noodle, and the science of a flawless ramen bowl."    I think they need to do a little more "learning" or stick to what they DID learn and not edit it to cater to a non-Japanese palate, because this statement obviously means nothing based on what they served.

Bjr4PH1BIJ7tSeQvs36jvA.text: WOWOWOWOW!!! FINALLY! After visiting Japan last year and being spoiled by the best ramen at every turn I have been looking to recreate the experience here in Phoenix. I had heard of Nishikawa Ramen but never had the desire to drive out to the east side and try it. I am so happy they opened a location closer to home. This is the closest to authentic ramen in Phoenix and I would say it's not far off from what I had in Tokyo. The tonkotsu broth is silky smooth and savory. The noodles are homemade and I may or may not have been slapped in the face with them because I was eating so fast! The pork chashu is generously portioned but you can add extra for $2. Clocking in at a whopping $9.95 it's a great deal. I've already been here three times in the last two weeks and I can't wait to try everything they offer!

GpPjqbkcKSWhpvw23uoQpw.text: Excellent Ramen. Rivals Monza in little Tokyo (Los Angeles). Ingredients and noodles very fresh, flavors quite vibrant. Will definitely return.

iUMjk7Ydf4x6f5BjeI4SIA.text: Both the curry n black Ramen are fantastic. The other menu items are good as well. We are big fans of great ramen and this is the best in town. Give them a try you won't be disappointed. I'm lucky I live only a few blocks away.

GbEr8SUO7RDye10QDvfhAw.text: I've had the food at the Chandler location and felt like it wasn't good - luckily some co-workers dragged me to the Phoenix location and it's much better than the one in Chandler.  Service is always prompt, even when the restaurant is super busy during the working lunch hours, which makes it pretty easy to take a 1 hour lunch, travel included.  For those who enjoy Japanese curry, I highly recommend the curry ramen. The broth is a thick and flavorful one that's ultra savory and leaves me feeling so satisfied and warm after. I usually modify mine by getting curly noodles instead of straight noodles, and a soft boiled egg instead of hard boiled. I've also had almost all of the appetizers, and my favorites are the takoyaki and ika geso karaage. The takoyaki is super hot but packed with flavor and a huge chunk of octopus. They're very generous on the toppings (kewpie mayo, sauce, and shaved bonito flakes) which was a welcome surprise. The ika geso karaage is fried super crisp on the outside but tender on the inside, again with great flavor. The dipping sauce that's served with it is so good that I'll take the bed of shredded cabbage that it's sitting on and use that as a vehicle for sauce.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Curry ramen with curly noodles
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Ika geso karaage

XIbatZbzZAuJp32U-tVkQA.text: Holy moly! Talk about great flavor. The ramen bowls here are superior in every way. They even ask you how you want your egg!  The menu is simple so it is easy to decide what to eat.   The actual eating space is small with only about 12 tables. Next time I'll count them.  I ordered a curry ramen bowl and I was very pleased with the flavor. The noodles were cooked to perfection and were infused with a spicy tang that complimented the rest of the ingredients.   They even asked me how I wanted my egg cooked. Not a question I expect to answer anytime after breakfast.  Overall a 5-star experience. Definitely a restaurant that deserves repeated visits.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Curry Ramen
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Wall art.

ZZrSmBUxCL6-KAaxh7-41g.text: So, I was a little hesitant to come here. After all, I ate a lot of ramen noodles when I was in college once upon a time, but this is nothing (let me repeat that NOTHING) like any ramen noodles I have had before. Maybe it's all about the additional ingredients and the way they cook this, but I'm hooked, particularly on the Nishikawa Black. So yummy!   Of course, you'll be tempted to eat the everything in your bowl because the flavors are that good, but if you don't, you can have leftovers for tomorrow. Disclaimer: I ate the whole bowl and was rather stuffed.  Service was also excellent. At 2 p.m. on a Sunday afternoon and the place was packed, but we didn't have to wait more than ten minutes before we were at a table. If you do have to wait, they will text you when your table is ready, just don't go too far.  So, I'm super excited about going back and slurping up that broth and those noodles because ramen has a whole new meaning to me.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Black truffle straight noodle yummy
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States

KzpADr9_sNNiSlWQ3o3rvw.text: Love love love love love this place. Nothing else I've tried in Scottsdale, Glendale, Tempe, Flagstaff and Tucson has come remotely close. Actually, the one in Tucson is really good too. But Nishikawa is hands down the best ramen in AZ.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States

tG0jpHXcUYE00d1G6GtGog.text: Nishikawa Ramen is absolutely delicious.  We discovered this place within the last few months and have already been here twice.  Can't wait to come again...  The first time, we ordered WAY too much food.  Ramen bowls here are gigantic, but we thought "oh, it's just soup" and went crazy on the appetizers.  And boy, are there some fun options for appetizers!  We had the pork gyoza, which were so good that we ended up ordering a second platter of them, with a touch of lacy crisp and some delicious flavor.  We also had some spring rolls and the takoyaki, which we'd never had before.  Apparently it's a bread-wrapped octopus ball with some moving fish flakes on top!  Only go for that one if you're in an adventurous mood, or if you're taking some shots of sake for courage.  We also had some spicy tuna on rice.  If you're a huge poki fan, I would skip this one, since it's very simple compared to what you're used to.  The ramen here is really the star of the menu, which you expect since you're at a ramen house.  My Nishikawa Black was so good that I want to go back and get another bowl while I'm sitting here writing about it.  Prices are incredible as well.  They're starting to have some wait times, since people are discovering this place, but that's too be expected.   Anyway.  Go.  Now.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Ramen!!!

5Gd5h4RjQBVseff-hcZFVg.text: Ive been to the east valley location years ago. It was amazing. I come to this location all the time. Thought id give them a much deserved 5star review. Def try the curry ramen! My favorite. Also the black ramen is amazing too.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Simple amazing. We always come here, idk why ive never given this place and the mesa location a 5 star review.

EDrz5DxzvLxZVuzfUpLlWQ.text: Solid ramen, the best I've had in Arizona!  Takoyaki was good. It tasted like it was fried rather than cooked on the steel molds (not sure what else to call them), and the only sauce it seemed to have was mayo but it was tasty!   The ramen noodles were nice and firm. I loved the garlic garnishes.    All in all a great place for a bowl of ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Nishikawa black ramen
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Takoyaki with katsuo overload

z8cgcGVdr874T4GL7VI_8g.text: Fabulous new ramen house in central Phoenix.  Weekdays it is not open all day, they break between lunch and dinner.  Plan accordingly as it gets busy and there aren't many tables.  You can sign in on Yelp though!  They are also picky about tables, you must have the same number of people in your party as there are chairs at the table.  This is very fair though due to the size of the place.  Trust me, its worth the wait.  Simple menu with a variety of appetizers and a few ramen choices.  I keep to pretty traditional pork ramen and add black garlic.  You can choose the noddles, but I stick with what it comes with, also traditional.  Another interesting option is how you want your egg cooked.  Soft boiled all the way for me!  Broth is hearth and full of flavor!    Craving ramen!  Be sure to stop by Nishikawa!  Enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States

LTv4hQ7Z5NwFpdEub5GGfg.text: This place is very busy. Go early so you don't need to wait in line!  They offer many different type of ramen. The black garlic paste is so delicious and addictive. I love Yokohama style ramen the most. I also like tonkotsu ramen. I need to go back and try all of their ramen.  We always got takoyaki or squid karaage. Takoyaki is yummy and they put lots and lots of bonito (dried fish flakes) on top. Making it extra delicious! Karaage is perfectly crisp and dipping it with mayo made me day.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Takoyaki
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Yokohama style ramen - medium hot

xTOPO6v-WWqX38R7jpXfuQ.text: So hard when you've had bay area ramen(santouka, ramen dojo, santa ramen..) to compare too.    Solid 3.5 like rounding up for new businesses and worth a try if you like ramen as ramen doesn't seem to be as big here yet (because its normally freaking HOT in phoenix lol)..  4 of 5 for Ramen in AZ  3 of 5 for Ramen Overall - for my ramen aficionados   Service was friendly(4/5)  Appetizers was on point  Takoyaki 5/5 - fried octopus goodness Chicken karage 4/5 - nicely seasoned crunchy and most chicken , went well with my sapporo   Ramen was good Nishikawa Ramen 3/5 - had black garlic oil and additional seasoning which gave a kick but not the added umami richness I look for in the broth..  Shio Ramen 3/5 - my hubby also sought the broth was missing the richness and umami that the bay area ramen have mastered plus a bit saltier (which is funny considering this is literally salt ramen but it's what he normally orders)  Straight noodles was average   Meat - pork chashu perfectly tender   Toppings - soft boiled egg was perfectly cooked, menma kikurage fried onions   Don't sit at the bar unless your over 6ft tall the top of the bowl was at my chin level (I'm 5ft tall shorty barely could see what was in my bowl lol).

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Nishikawa Ramen
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Karage
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Takoyaki

zA9iILUIYZsh4OhApqNzhA.text: Second time coming here.  Had their ramen, bowl, and appetizer.   Miso spicy ramen at HOT level is pretty on point. They don't go easy on the spice and I appreciate that. Some places really dumb down the concept of "hot". The chashu meat that comes with the ramen is decent.   Ordered the chashu bowl - it's on the smaller side but in the end it fulfilled my hunger. The downside to the bowl is that they only give one slice of meat. Paying 6 dollars for a tiny bowl I was hoping I could get one more.   The takoyaki was mediocre - it's more fried than I'm used to but oddly enough it was very mushy inside with one piece of octopus. It's missing the bonito flakes on top too.   Overall it's decent. It's the closest ramen to me in Arcadia so will definitely come back again to try other items.  They were playing Korean songs here - have to give them thumb up for that.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States

ga7S1YX2eSHe-vHkHf_bVA.text: Superb noodles!   Recently went here for a weekday lunch with some friends from work.  We were greeted by a cheerful waitress and seated immediately.    The menu was simple and reasonably priced.  The Ika Geso Karaage was fun and yummy.   My Tonkotsu was savory without being over indulgent. One additional slice of pork in the Tonkotsu would be nice!   The beef bowl that my friend ordered was very small but very delicious.  He was surprised by the small size of the dish, however, given its low cost, he should not have been surprised.   The service was excellent.  We were given a pitcher of water so we didnt have to wait for water.  The waitress was cordial and attentive but stayed out of our way and allowed us to fully enjoy our meals without interruption, though she checked in at just the right moments in an undisturbing way.  Excellent balance of being attentive while not disturbing the diners' enjoyment of their meals.   I am happy that we stopped in and I am sure to visit again and again, very good noodles and good service at a good price.  Thank you!

hz4226jSrL2EYI35ziIH3A.text: Ramen is delicious and the service was great!!! My boyfriend and I loved it can't wait to come back again

-Utxv7FMKlPGoOzJa9o7YQ.text: Small spot, but it gives off a very authentic feel.   The gyoza is really good and the ramen has a large portion size.   Wish there was a larger selection of drinks (hint hint milk tea )   Was caught off guard by the hours - they close at 2:30 on some days, but otherwise I really like this place!

pXSIJneh05yrhiMeifZExQ.text: Stopped by for my 2nd visit today. Tried the medium Yokohama Ramen - delicious with a kick! Also had the Nishikawa Black both were great! Service was solid. I'll be here again for sure to try something new.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Yokohama Ramen &amp; Gyoza
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Yokohama style medium spicy with kikurage

-WfS_wTTHmi16ElHLrNn6Q.text: Okay - hands down the best ramen in the valley.   I don't know what else to say, other than try it! You'll love it!!!!   The restaurant can feel a bit small, but that's only because they are so popular! If you come during a peak time, expect to wait a bit. But it's SO WORTH IT!   The first time I came here we tried almost all the apps, their gyoza is super delicious and by far my favorite.  We've also tried their bowls which was quite tasty as well.   Always have had friendly service and really enjoyed the experience of eating there. After writing this review... I'm now craving their ramen so I guess I'll see you here tomorrow! ;)

eK55qrVlMGrvaf8sbDo3EA.text: The Ramen is ok. Their fried chicken was a little disappointed. Overall one of the best places near Phoenix airport.

Nn3hISP8k0do5wL-PIihFw.text: Small restaurant. Looks family owned. Japanese style menu.  Deep fried squid: fried squid on top of cabbage with a honey mustard dipping sauce. Very good texture of chewy and crunchy. Salty and sweet taste.  Spicy tuna over rice: spicy tuna mix on top of warm rice and seaweed salad. Tasty. Not too spicy. Small serving. Be sure to get one more for item asking with this.  Tonkatsu ramen: kind of simple tasting until you add the red pepper on the table to bring it up a level. Not the best ramen I've had but it's ok.  Service is friendly and clean. Parking is lot and spacious

y702Avjo71_gpw_tJ1_mAA.text: My daughter loves her some ramen...as do I, so when we heard about Nishikawa, we had to check it out!  We both ordered our favorites and, happily, they offer soft and hard boiled seasoned eggs (I like 'em soft, my daughter likes 'em hard boiled - often, it's one, or the other, so one of us isn't thrilled with the options).  We went the first time when my wife was out of town, and discovered there were several other-than-ramen options on the menu (she's not a ramen-hound the way we are).  We brought her with us the next time, and everybody enjoyed their orders.    Cool spot, nice folks, good ramen - what's not to love??   :-)

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Miso ramen

V8P-gZD5wsogafzgqkzsMw.text: Very small restaurant=small wait. Not good for big groups getting together. Took a while for someone to tend to your table. No drink menu. I believe they serve Japanese beer out of a can if you're looking for alcohol. Simple menu of delicious ramen-straight or curly ramen and not over or under-cooked. Tonkotsu soup base was on point-oily, heavy, thick & creamy. Add- ins to the soup were delicious. Cha-shu was thick, juicy, good flavor and fatty . Be patient with the service; seems like they are still trying to work out a few kinks.

ilkw8_Oxzt2b0zCY5_Psvg.text: After two visits this is decidedly our go to "Ramen Place". Multiple flavors to choose from - and you can have them increase the spiciness of the dish.   I got the Miso Soup at medium spicy - excellent flavor and tempting to gorge if you have no self control. Big chewy noodles. The boiled egg was deliciously brown from broth water. The pork was extremely tender with delicate lines of fat running through.   A cozy restaurant - easy to find seating if you're only a party of 2. Big groups, come prepared to wait 30mins - 1hr to push a few tables together.   Servers are friendly - just make sure to stand your ground if you're still eating. Sometimes they can rush you a bit when they're others parties waiting to be seated.   I hear they're going to open up more locations soon.

hGjsAhGevZtFDge9L-KaUA.text: What ever drive you're about to make to make it here do it. Its beyond worth it. Ive been to several ramen shops in the area and this one is by far my favorite. You get an incredible bang for your buck and the service was great. Only downside is the seating. But we made it work. Ramen, appetizers, sodas and teas were all on point and picture perfect.

HqreOpGCcWkJqBCgJOdKkg.text: Yum! The perfect meal for a cold day! So happy to have a vegetarian option. Ramen was delicious. Very flavorful broth with lots of yummy stuff in it. Very large portion, enough to take home for a second meal. The spicy garlic edamame was yummy and well priced. Hot sake just added to the experience. Highly recommend this place!

ku0SGg6i_ACPgxHetXp6cQ.text: This is the best ramen I've found in the Phoenix area.  The Tonkotsu ramen is AMAZING!  The broth is super flavorful and the other items are fresh and delicious.  It was also reasonably priced - around $10 for ramen.  I would definitely recommend giving this a try!

ZtJhwhD_eESh_P9D7mzu_Q.text: Found a good ramen place in Phoenix!! Totally recommend the Nishikawa black ramen!! The bowl is affordable too. Will try one next time

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Sake bomber $8 for all this!!
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Nishikawa black noodle

bJhPfozxSfox_-YzQBIluw.text: We weren't expecting anything amazing but this place was awesome. It was packed on a Sunday night and the ramen is truly delicious.

NhhN5jl6coZih1tQrhoCDw.text: YAAAAAAAAAAAS  I recently moved from LA and whenever I've felt homesick, this is where I go for Asian food that's as good as I could get back in SoCal. Having tried most of their basic ramens, I recommend the tonkatsu, the shio and the miso in that order. And, ALWAYS GO WITH THE SOFT BOILED EGG. That's the move right there. Reserving one star for re-reviewing in the future. I've visited 4 times in 3 weeks and will definitely be back again soon!

oZkpI4jGc_lDoAJjTlcqNw.text: This is definitely the best place on earth for ramen. I am a picky eater and love to cook. The nishikawa black punches you in the mouth with flavor. Originally from Chicago (went to Asu awhile ago) so the food in Phoenix cannot even compare. However, this is the closest I've found to food as good as Chicago. I bring all my friends who visit from home here and everyone I know in Phoenix here! Best ramen hands down.

C79VitSfWWe9ycrxndAfhQ.text: Went here for lunch on a Saturday afternoon and left feeling full and satisfied!  Pro's  ~Great assortment of items on menu to choose from ~Menu is laid out nicely and makes it super easy for those that are new to ramen ~Perfect amount of selection without making it overwhelming  ~Food came out nice and piping hot ~Friendly and knowledgable staff ~Very clean (bathroom too A+++)  Con's  ~Parking? This is located in a high traffic shopping area so that's really the only thing I can think of  Can't wait to come again soon!

h2l4OP2m3W8A63d_EgYjYA.text: This is a good place, but I'm not giving them 5 stars because last time I went the broth tasted different, not bad, but it wasn't creamy. It was almost as if they had watered it down. Pay attention to that just in case they do this again, then write your own review.

Ve8CtqthkTsW3B5xBfXgIg.text: Good Ramen! We decided to try it after seeing some pictures on yelp. I'm from Hawaii and we have A LOT (maybe too many lol) of ramen shops, and this place hit the spot after being away from the island for a while. We tried the Shio, Miso, Tonkotsu, Nishikawa Black, and the Yokohama style. Everyone was satisfied, as it tasted just like it does back home. Gyoza was also pretty good. The prices were good in comparison to portion and taste :) my only complaint was that it was a tad bit salty, and the spicy options aren't very spicy. I'd skip medium and go with hot if you like spicy food.  tldr; if you want a good bowl of ramen, this is the spot!

_1zHEm5U7Os6FSEQQPEaig.text: Definitely my new favorite ramen spot in phx. I had the nishikawa the first time and it was absolutely delicious and the miso ramen today with a side of extra noodles so I can eat with the left over broth .. I'd definitely recommend this place YUM YUM YUM

QUDniCc5sFpSZtJlVGvpnA.text: Best Ramen i've had in phoenix so far and i've tried a couple. very unimpresed by ramen time that was higher rated and everyone seems to be in love with. The tonkotsu was good had decent flavor and we enjoyed the chicken karage and the gyoza. i'll be back again for sure.

O3i8_4WC4t_0w3ZXMlXwiA.text: Just finished our first meal here. It's amazing!! Our table had the brisket beef bowl, the fried chicken, gyoza, miso ramen and the curry ramen. All were fantastic! Will be going back and telling friends about it.

YmKEv31etgVvVR15BacMIw.text: This place has a good reputation, from people who don't know good food. Spring rolls are frozen, tuna scooped out of a bucket like ice cream, and the place in general smells like a dirty mop. Enjoy!

jyqy1OFxwr_9fApHMzFs6Q.text: I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen and it was good.  I got an extra egg, cooked medium boiled.  It was delicious.  Service was fast and prompt.

9wdOerw3UowmAtGqZ1AmLQ.text: I was craving a bowl of warm ramen and when I discovered this new spot opened right by me I knew I had to check it out. We were greeted the moment we walked in and we were able to seat ourselves. The place is a bit small but has a fun feel to it. Immediately our server brought us glasses and a jar of water. We started off with the Chicken Gyoza, which had a light crispy texture and were very tasty. I then had the Tonkotsu Ramen with a bit of powdered chili spice, it was delicious! I will go back to check out the rest of the Ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States

6OVpgYN2lUmIxLNXctfG4Q.text: Very tasty ramen, authentic and very close to what we had in Japan. Definitely worth going there if you're in the area.

sEbKW6iMtL9e2sG4WdlohQ.text: This is our favorite Ramen place in town; we have been here several times and tried all the different Ramens from their menu!! Nisikawa Black is the best and I also like the Curry one. The chicken karaage are a bit overcooked but apparently that's because they have had complaints about undercooked chicken. Great place for a hot bowl of flavorful ramen!!

Tsm7QEmGiX3Em58dTH9Ihw.text: All three of our sons Live in Manhattan and they have the best Ramen.  I have not found a good place in comparison. I am no expert but I think the flavor here is very good.   I ordered the Nishikawa Black medium spicy with my egg soft boiled.  An order of pork Gyoza dumplings and mango cream soda. Everything here was clean fast and friendly.  I even took an order to go for my husband.   I I will tell my friends about it. It is approximately 30 minutes away from my house, however I would make the drive to come and eat here

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Black Nishikawa with a soft boiled egg
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pork Gyoza dumplings. Mango cream soda. Water Carafe and water cup.

rtE_NZnkMlZKd9EcQLKD4g.text: Good Ramen Place. Noodles had a good chew and the pork broth had a good flavor. I would have like more umami and round notes if that makes sense.   No kids menu but they did offer noodles and broth only for my daughter at a reduced price, which was nice. My son gobbled up the beef bowl.

nrvnCARI-ueXwppEALnMgQ.text: Good: - Atmosphere cozy.  - Friendly servers, fast to bring water, with carafe to self serve. - Orders taken quickly, and efficiently. - Broth very good, salty, but noodle soup broth is made that way. - Thin noodles very good and easy to eat, cooked just right. - Soft boiled egg is like medium, just to my liking. - Some crunchy radish julienned was good touch, onions just right, thinly sliced across. - Iced tea, unsweetened, was very good after I got used to the different taste. Came in a plastic to go cup that seems reusable. - Gyoza softer than expected. Most places fry it too much and the skin gets hard. This was crunchy on edges, but soft on sides. Delicious sauce and meat.  Not so good: - Small seating area, limited seats.  - Out of squid legs. With a limited menu, would think they'd have a very good handle on supply and demand and have inventory well controlled after a year at this location. - No free refills on the iced teas. Unusual. Even if it's special tea, it's still likely relatively inexpensive. - Pork seemed to be boiled, making the meat tough. Used to it being slow roasted, and super tender, this is the Asian way. Here, quick boil was the way sadly. - My friend didn't want to use chopsticks. Recommend a no fork policy.   Summary: - Still overall very good first visit. Would go again and again. Limited ramen places. If the idea catches on and more ramen places pop up, that may help improve on the weaknesses.

pBQHR8PkcGw_6EJ-zDXTgQ.text: I decided the visit when my layover in Phoenix was extended by a flight delay. It was only 15 minutes away, and the reviews were solid. The ramen is in the top 3 I've had, it's super flavorful and everything is prepared with care. I especially liked the smoked onion oil, which I haven't seen anywhere else. Service was outstanding, my order came out quickly and I had no problem getting back in time for my flight. I'll be back the next time I'm in Phoenix!

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Delicious black ramen, with a perfectly cooked soft egg.

P3JSYukoDuGlprWcuYEq6A.text: So I lived in Asia years ago. And a decade later, there are some parts of Asia that I still carry with me....and that's my palette. I had a taste for some Ramen and as always I turned to my foodie BFF Yelp. She rarely steers me wrong  I took a study break, dropped in, sat at the bar, ordered and studied my pharmacology cards. My ramen was out in NO time. Let me tell you, that broth is EVERYTHANG! I mean sheesh, that's the base of the ramen. Bad broth, bad ramen! Welp not here! They note that they boil their broth for 20 hours and I can certainly believe it! Thanks to the cook who keeps his eyes on it that long, or actually remembers to check on it! You're the real MVP! The noodles are made from scratch! And its obvious!!!! And don't you dare order without getting a boiled egg. That egg seals the meal! I was so impressed. Literally a taste of Japan with every bite! I will be sure to visit again! Go check out it out y'all! It's worth the hype! It's affordable, fast and the service was good. I have zero complaints....other than not having a pot of that broth in my freezer.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States

TEZyNlfdfvuJXSAYOHH7sw.text: Forget Sosoba and Clever Koi, this place is my new favorite for Ramen stop in the Valley. Omg, thank you Yelpers, I found this gem.   Okay, the area is small but don't just judge yet because the food is mind blowing. We went in around 5 pm, no wait line, got seated quickly. Placed our orders, Spicy miso ramen (hot), Karage Chicken and Pork Gyoza. All the items came hot and fresh. God, those Gyozas were so so good, so much close to what I had in Japan in terms of taste.  Coming to Chicken Karage, they were tasty. Light breading and perfectly fried, crispy yet flavorful. Last, the ramen. The noodles was perfectly cooked, the egg was soft boiled, got the runny yolk on my ramen with soft pork chasu. I also added a side of garlic oil and it enriched the flavor. Not to forget, the broth was superb.   Can't wait to go back and try the black ramen! Highly recommend this place for ramen lovers. The price, quality of food, and customer service does so much justice to this place. No wonder they are always busy.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Karage Chicken and Pork Gyoza, The Best!
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pork Gyoza

BfepLbCLUcLsqgeXePhAHw.text: This is simply a wonderful Ramen noodle place. Everything I had was great. I had the tonKatsu Ramen and some really amazing spring rolls.  Although the food was simply great they could definitely work on their service skills. But overall I would recommend this Ramen joint without hesitation.

0xJQi23RRkRW7q_RhVCFhg.text: This place is incredible. Best Ramen I've had in Phoenix for sure, highly recommend the Nishikawa Black is   We got here at 7pm and by 7:45, there wasn't a seat to be had. So plan to get there earlier!

We're definitely going to be back to try some of the other types of ramen.

HLhbPgYtAeHUnFlhfMqbIA.text: Amazing! Their ramen is a step above the rest with intensely layered flavors and unique combinations. I can't get enough of the Nishikawa Black. We will definitely be coming back for more!

AfdC3l0c3r930YY7HRR33Q.text: In my opinion, this is one of the best places in Phoenix for ramen so far! I wish the place was in a bigger location but nonetheless, my boyfriend and I enjoyed eating here. Very cute atmosphere. The service is great and very attentive. We ordered the Yokohama style ramen and the Tonkotsu ramen along with the side order of takoyaki. So so soooo good! I recommend for anyone who is craving ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States

KAuMPekzGyUiKp8zpMMHzw.text: Pretty consistent ramen and sides. I usually get the nishikawa black which you can adjust the spice level. The karaage is pretty good. The ikura roe and men taiko rice bowls are ok too. Perfect place for comfort food especially on a cool or rainy day.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Spicy miso and nishikawa black

oi9cKOkrl_Qpw0dQ9Q698A.text: It's the best ramen I've had in Phoenix so far and I intended on going back to try some of their other varieties.  They do a good job with the broth and the noodles which is most of the battle.  The broth was thick, fatty, and flavorful.  Other places just don't make strong broth, like they're afraid to be bold and turn people off or something.  I dunno.  This place makes it with a gusto which makes it so different.  I'm not a huge fan of the thin noodles (even when I lived in Japan) but they're authentic.  The karaage is a US version of it with more fat and fried parts and less chunky chicken.  Not sure what the sauce was, but they could probably improve the dish with more flavor in the batter and a couple of thinner sauces.  The texture overall was good.  Friendly service, easy parking, they bring a water carafe to your table (I was thirsty when I came in so that was nice).  Plus, the ramen is under $10.  I really hate "gourmet" $15 ramen places.  Ramen is one of the cheapest meals you can get in Japan, not fine dining, and doesn't need expensive fakeness.  It just needs  flavor.  It's a small place, and one thing I didn't like was that the tables are close together.  I grabbed a seat at the high countertop and was there before noon but as more and more people came in you could see how close things were.  I guess in an odd way you can it's authentic Tokyo.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Miso, medium spicy, no corn.
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chicken Karaage, $6.95
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Tonkatsu ramen minus the green onion.  $9.95

xTRzFyQDj1f0l0T1_RBOKw.text: Had to find a new ramen place around the Phoenix area and decided to try this place out with a coworker. It's a tiny little place, but works well as the flow of people were in and out and I didn't feel like I was cramped in.   Decided to try the Tonkotsu traditional ramen with a soft boiled egg. The pricing was pretty fair compared to the food they give you. The broth was pretty standard for the ramen. Nothing extravagant. Add ons like garlic oil is a $1.50 more which I thought was ridiculous. For some oil? Really?   Also tried the takoyaki and it was pretty fair tasting compared to others in the Phoenix area. They added a lot of the flakes on top which I liked, but that's personal preference.   I think what makes this review average is the service. We sat at the bar, and the waitress was...cold? Indifferent? Didn't greet us when we came in, just looked at us, said "for two?" them directed us to the bar when asked if we wanted to sit there. There wasn't any interaction or friendly demeanor. When we got the check she just placed it on the table. That was it. I mean, part of the job is enacting good customer service, one that I believed  she definitely missed the mark on and made me less inclined to want to come back again.   Definitely still on the hunt for a good ramen place.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States

RYDM567oeHgTtNwxvlH33A.text: My favorite Ramen spot in Phoenix. Chasu is on point. Broth is rich and flavorful. Service is great. Food quick and comes out steaming hot.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Spicy Miso Ramen extra soft egg.

y6K76c8TczaASwofayq8kA.text: Let me start off with saying I'm a big tonkotsu ramen fan. I travel often to Japan and love trying different Tonkotsu restaurants. I'm currently in Phoenix trying to find a place that can compare to the ramen in Japan. Nishikawa doesn't quite live up to it. The atmosphere was relaxing and the waitress was very friendly. With that said, I'm not saying Nishikawa has bad ramen. If you're looking for a mediocre bowl of Tonkotsu, then give it a try, but if you're looking for something that can compare up to REAL Japanese Tonkotsu then Nishikawa isn't the place for you.

pCSsfMNw4j5-cNJnMWidIA.text: Stopped in for a quick light bite. Sat at bar. They have a nice selection of cold Sake and Japanese beer. Ordered-the traditional ramen with egg soft boiled.  Food came out quick and was fresh.  Super reasonable prices, bill was just over $10. Nice option for lunch during the week.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States

DZJ6l31Fddxeke4e-6x4dg.text: Okay ever since we went to Japan a few years ago we have been on a hunt to find ramen that could compare to the delicious unique culinary experience we had at Ichiran. Tried so many places, some good, some bad, never quite hit the umami spot. No luck until NOW! Nishikawa brought us right back to Japan, nearly brought tears to our eyes :) My husband and I absolutely loved and enjoyed every last drop of the rich flavorful tonkotsu broth and the perfect noodles! Highly recommend the Nishikawa black ramen-- we love spicy ramen so we got HOT and were not disappointed!  To be honest with you, we were only in town for 3 days and we ate here twice :) OISHII!!  Thank you for the great food and hope to visit again next time we go to Phoenix!

IpGgodonOjaqeyUHud7BKA.text: This place is much better now compared to when it first opened. The servers are really nice and attentive. It gets busy during dinner time and they don't have that much seating inside. Food is good. I always get the Nishikawa black. It used to be really salty that I had to add water to it but now it's much better. The tonkatsu ramen is also good. Don't order the takoyaki. It's mostly breading. I'd rather order the deep fried calamari!  Price is also not cheap but not too expensive as well. I would go back here again for some ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Nishikawa black

P8PwRinXvnJiRxvzDl7ybQ.text: Very flavorful! This is the classic ramen with authentic tasting soup you can get in west coast!

Ns6DmjnpBXx4-U42g45ujw.text: Great taste is the best way to describe here! The sake was good. You eat quick and tasty at the same time. I will be back soon.

7yxPQ5p4mEC1TxYun_n9Vg.text: Ordered the Yokohama style ramen, the noodles were well cooked but the broth tasted a bit fishy. Some of the other bowls did read that as a ingredient on the menu, but the bowl I got did not so not sure why it had that flavor.   The pork was tender and tasty. The egg, in which I look forward to eating when I have ramen, was not soft boiled it was hard boiled. So when eating it in the broth it had a powdery consistency which was not so appetizing.   I did like how they serve you water in a carafe with lemon and ice and the staff in there were very nice.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States

DnMsQQjNRhNYdVPGln5ozQ.text: Hit/Miss, unfortunately. I went in for dinner and got a seat right away - plus. The waitress didn't show up for a while with the menu - minus. Once she showed up, I asked if they had Wi-Fi and imagine my surprise when she said no, they didn't, as if that's something natural at an eatery nowadays - minus, SMH.   The Chicken Kaarage was acceptable, but the pieces were all fried stuck together, so it was impossible to eat with chopsticks - minus. Of course, they were not on hand to offer other utensils. Seriously folks, if your story 'begins in Nishikawa,' you should know that Asian food is cut into bite-size pieces specifically so it can be eaten with chopsticks. I received 1/9th of a lemon, or a thin lemon slice - minus.    The Ika Geso Karaage was absolutely amazing, down to the Kewpie mayo - big, big plus. Although I was originally going to order the Tonkotsu Ramen, I went for the Nishikawa Black as recommended. They don't use Ramen noodles, but rather thin straight Soba noodles for this one - not good.   SMH, I should have read the fine print. I prefer Ramen to Soba, in part because Ramen's flavor and al dente. The Soba was not cooked and came in a cold clump on the bottom of the bowl, so I had to let the broth soften it for about 15 minutes by which time the broth was cold, so I didn't enjoy my Nishikawa Black experience. I want to come back to this restaurant to try the Tonkotsu Ramen, but for now this is overall a two-star experience.   This is also worth mentioning; if you happen to enjoy soothing, Zen-type music, don't give this place a try. I was assaulted by bad hip-hop mixes the whole time I was there, so my next 'experience' will be strictly pick-up.

XIF23CjYu9SUfFDV0CQIUA.text: On my first visit they took FOREVER to bring us our order.  It wasnt that busy when we got there and we had put our order.  Shortly after more patrons started coming in.  I saw 3 tables that came in after us get their order first. When I noticed that I think they forgot about our order, the waitress noticed me and had this  face.  She shortly later came over and said our food will be right out.   Now keep in mind it was 30mins since we ordered and we still hadnt gotten our edamame and other appetizer we ordered.  It all came out together which made us want to rush.  I was going to rate it then and give them a 2 star, however the RAMEN WAS SOOOO GOOD.   Needless to say i been back there several more times lol, and have not experienced this delay that I did on my first visit.  No joke, GREAT FOOD!

M8YUBHtNQx8Uqlr0eIq3LQ.text: Some of the best ramen I've had. Top contender in Phoenix. Gyoza and karaage chicken are great

H-fUpp4LX6vs8w93HUk3cA.text: Dream Ramen  I've searched for authentic Ramen in Phoenix since moving here, and Niahikawa did not disappoint! The place itself is smaller, but in a cute, cozy way. I had the Tonkotsu Black, and it was everything I've hoped for in a ramen, a rich, flavorful broth, tasty, well constructed noodles, and varied toppings all in a balanced filling portion. The distant location is the only reason I'm not here all the time!

jnK3dvSwlPPARR4RM5LrBg.text: The spicy curry raman was perfect, most "hot" things aren't hot for me but this place actually made it where I was able to taste the heat.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States

WeSc8-QldGT2gUJlHf8x0g.text: Best Ramen in Phoenix for sure! Somewhat small space, but modern and casual. I had the Curry Ramen, SOFT boiled egg, medium spicy, and the Chicken Karrage on the side. Next time I will opt for one of the more traditional broths, for some reason I was envisioning yellow curry. This was more of a red curry, but STILL delicious. The pork broth has a great Umami flavor. Would love a ramen bowl with Chicken Karrage already in it, that's why I got the Chicken Karrage appetizer. I was trying to copycat another place in San Fransisco that does it like that. The peanut sauce the chicken came with was pretty tasty. All in all, if you are looking for a great ramen place in Phoenix, this is it! And worth the trip!  P.S. Medium spicy was nice. I like things spicy, this had a nice amount of spice, while not overpowering the flavor of the dish.

CPMtx1cWG8YA5Ow9EucUKg.text: I called this order in to-go, and we both got the Miso Ramen and gyoza. I liked the gyoza, it had good flavor, texture, and the sauce that came with it was yummy. As far as the ramen though....I liked the texture and flavor of the noodles, but Overall I didn't enjoy the ramen overly much, for one main reason. The broth.  The broth we got (so I'm not saying that's how it always is) but the broth we got was bland and quite greasy. I could taste the porkiness, which was nice, but never I my life have I had a miso broth that tasted like it needed salt. So I was a little disappointed.  May go back another time to try another type of ramen though. And Maybe we'll eat in next time.  The place was packed, it smelled good, and the customer service was great.

sbbwNov9803ANXDEEQwZKw.text: This place was a little disappointing in terms of their food. The food was very salty and I couldn't even finish the food. It looked good and the presentation was good but the taste Didn't match the food and presentation that was in the bowl.   I don't think I'll be back at this establishment again nor will I recommend it to anyone. I was really disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Nishikawa Ramen - Phoenix, AZ, United States

CKRnvGZgrJS3J-t9IbM9zg.text: I have finally found some amazing ramen in the valley! I was big into pho until I had ramen at Furious Spoon during a trip Chicago and it changed my life. I have since searched back in my hometown of AZ for some decent ramen as some shops have opened up but they have been lackluster at best. Until today, I finally stopped by Nishikawa. It is a quaint little ramen restaurant that was relatively full on a Saturday afternoon for lunch. I had their traditional ramen and it was delicious. You can add spicyness to your bowl, but I opted against that as I wanted to try it as is. At first I thought it was a bit bland but as I continued to eat and mix the ingredients around, the broth became much more rich and flavorful. I also had the pork gyoza which was really good as well. It had a nice little crispy crunch to it as it seemed to be pan seared just briefly on one side. Added a nice texture to the otherwise soft nature of it. I also liked that they leave a carafe of water at your table as well so you can refill your water as you'd like. They have green tea and various other Japanese beverages too. They will be having liquor very soon as they are just waiting for their liquor license to arrive in the mail. Prices were decent as well for the ramen and add ins. The bowl was $10 and add ins about $1.50. Appetizers are about $2-6 but you got 6 gyoza for the $6. It was delicious and I will be back for more!

4JaGoU2quEkzNldWppHS1A.text: It's fair. It's edible. If you are vegetarian... I would skip it. The broth is basically water and they don't take the time to make a proper veg stock. I eat it when I am cold, in the area and want more than tea. But it's overcrowded (the tables are so close together), slow service and not great food. However, it happens to be in an area I am around quite often.  Their noodles aren't very great either. If you want GOOD NOODLES, go to Clever Koi. Best I have had in the Valley.   p.s. I find it a bit pricey and it reminds me of fast food! I would rather go get some good Pho somewhere! YES I realize they are totally different flavors, but at least Pho will have SOME flavor depending on where you go!

TAxlLY7CE_9gVsrMf3_PDw.text: A friend recommended this place so we gave it a try last weekend. We were early so the place wasn't busy yet. Our servers were attentive and kept checking on us. We tried a number of items including gyoza, takoyaki, two types of ramen (disappointed though they ran out of chicken karaage).  The appetizers were decent but didn't necessarily blow us away. The ramen on the other hand were really good. Great broth and we loved their curly noodles; my order came with straight noodles (you can see which noodles each bowl comes with by looking at the detailed description on the menu) and while they were fine we definitely preferred the texture of the curly ones.  Happy to see more decent ramen places popping up in the valley. We will be back!

gEks74hn3vdJIOCgnIs_-w.text: WHY IS THIS SOOOO YUMMY!!  Addictive Affordable And happening again very soon. The White Peach drink was really tasty too. I got 1 to go and added Sake at home... Great pairing.

inJHjuxDeEOuzNBFvbmRgQ.text: So hard to find good, authentic Ramen in Phoenix after living in Japan. This is my new go to place. It's the real deal and keeps me coming back. Their Garlic Edamame and Gyoza are equally delicious and authentic. Yum. 5 stars.

AOmuufX-pYwZsrqgSa5f5A.text: The Curry is to die for! The bowl was big the pork was juicy and delicious, it was perfect and very satisfying for the tummy.

lhu0XYCDgzmA9FUNYM35nQ.text: Wow!  This place was jumping on a Sunday noontime but we got a table for two. Lots of families and couples of all ages. But the food?  Outstanding!  The flavors burst. The textures of all dimensions. This all is just another example of culinary excellence!

B3_68e6m4H6L2OVILT3ACA.text: Really disappointed in the "service". I arrived around 650pm and I knew it was busy and expected a wait. I put my name on the list and was told to expect a 45 min to an hour wait. We were okay with that. I was so excited to try the food that I sat and waited at an outdoor table for my name to be called. With a party of four, I knew seating us might be difficult, but around 740 I excited to see the waitress putting extra chairs around a table. I was finally about to get in. Unfortunately the waitress came out to say they had called my name 15-20 minutes prior and no one answered because no one was outside. That was a pretty bold lie considering I had been sitting there watching the delivery orders go out for the past 35ish minutes. Then she said the manager even called my name... again, a lie. I would like to say they seated us immediately and apologized for the wait, but instead she said it would be an additional 25 minutes....We did not stay because at this point we are all too hungry to wait any longer, even though the smells coming out of the to go bags were heavenly. Hopefully in the future I am able to actually review the food, but it's just not in the cards tonight.

SVaA_g4JQOYPFHAXDaVmFQ.text: The tonkotsu soup was no real tonkotsu flavor..But I liked Ikura bowl.There was  some fruits taste sake that I wanted try! I have never seen when I was in Japan before! also Takoyaki was good.

vaNYl8npA666mY-C4vG3rw.text: Left so full and satisfied it was painful. Great food!! Only has one bathroom though so it was awkward waiting to use it.

Ez3Ulf-RuhIAHaaPz5PDDQ.text: Great ramen spot!! Been there a few times and tried different items each time. They are all awesome and flavorful but my favorite is the Nishikawa Black ramen! Very rich broth and full of flavor. Will definitely continue to come here!!

wuoJQiSAFVVSO_j8rvGqsQ.text: Ate here during my trip to AZ, and it's one of my least favorite bowls of ramen i've had. The space is decent, the service was alright, but the ramen was sub-par. The broth tasted like old pork water, The noodles were too thin for my liking, but to be fair that's more personal preference. The pork tasted bad, and the noodles didn't have any flavor whatsoever. Plus, I tried a bite of their pork & rice bowl, and the pork tasted like fish. It was disgusting. Would not recommend.

rBW0gcc8iUt3MiedQZRtDg.text: I'm obsessed with this restaurant.  I went two days in a row on very hot summer days but not even 110 degree weather could keep me away.  The menu is small and simple but totally perfect.  The first Ramen I tried was their Tonkotsu. The broth was super flavorful and not too salty; the hard boiled egg had that amazing pork broth saturated all the way through.  I was not sure if I would like the straight noodles but not only did I like them,  I now prefer them over the wavy ones! For the first time in my life I actually finished a whole bowl of Ramen,  broth and all.  And that's how I knew I had to go again the next day to try a different one! They get all 5 stars because the food is amazing,  the service is fast and attentive,  the prices are fair,  the place is cozy and clean,  and I love how they leave you with your own carafe of water infused wth lemon.  I can't wait to go back and try all of their Ramen dishes.

YYH6h0keF1ik-eogi1wIaA.text: Lunch yesterday.  Spicy salmon bowl (yum!) and Tonkatsu ramen with a soft egg.  Seriously delicious.  Served by the lovely Brie.  We have traveled to Japan and this comes very close to our first bowl of ramen in Osaka.  Beer was cold, sake was hot, and we were delighted.  My only comments would be the inane newscasters on the television.  Why not project some Anime?  Certainly glad we were not "assaulted" by loud music, as one reviewer commented.  But, perhaps some old Kurosawa?  Would be oh so much more fun.  Oh, and some grilled shishito peppers?  And perhaps golden curry on rice to accompany your fried chicken?

Zr-JNYPcUD1bRYLbB0x41g.text: Literally best ramen in Arizona. The food reminded me a lot of the ramen in Japan while the restaurant itself reminded me of the ramen shops in Melbourne. I'll be going back.

Vbg0--7dYLP5a1DtDU4-yg.text: We found our new ramen spot. This place is amazing. 12 minutes from our apartment in downtown Phoenix. We found it on Yelp and had to try it out as our bellies were growling for some delicious food past normal dinner time on a Saturday night. We got to the restaurant around 9pm and there were two to three other tables. They left as we were ordering. At the time we were the only customers. The server took our order and even asked what we'd like to have on the TVs. The gyoza arrived first and very quickly. I got the pork gyoza and they were perfect, soft yet crispy in all the right places. The ponzu sauce for dipping was delicious with multiple flavors happening at once and the green onion giving it that bite. The two bowls of ramen arrived shortly after. My wife got the tonkatsu ramen with the housemade noodles. I got the miso ramen. The broth was so full of depth and richness. The flavor was amazing. All of the ingredients inside worked together so well for your typical miso ramen. My belly is so full and happy. The service was amazing and so was the food. We'll be back for sure to earn our free bowl of ramen after scarfing down ten bowls.

-fFtN8jlCw_qoHVzfT0Kcw.text: AVOID AT ALL COSTS!! Read on for more: I was sad to see that Nishikawa had received a poor rating from the health department a few months ago and have steered clear until Saturday when I was craving a bowl of savory, delicious ramen. Nishikawa has been my go-to ramen fix since I returned from Japan after spending 19 blissful, ramen-rich years in Japan. Nishikawa used to be the closest I could find to genuine, savory ramen. The bowl of ramen I was served on Saturday was not the worst I've ever had, buy it was a close second. The broth was tasteless when it should have been rich and savory, the shashu which should melt in your mouth, was rubberry, the noodles were over cooked, the toppings were minimal, AND the yolk of the hard boiled egg was cold when it should have been warm at least. The shashu bowl was decent, but the skimped too much on the shashu. My greatest disappointment is my last best hope for a decent bowl of ramen has vanished here in Phoenix now.

pTJwD9Z4JcyN8UiF2JXZSQ.text: As much as I want a unique ramen spot to thrive in Arizona, i want it to be one that's ran correctly and thus this spot is not one I'd recommend due to it's poor design and even worse service. We were told be a staff member to go outside upon entering as there was a wait which didn't seem like an issue. After waiting for a bit and seeing other parties enter we were a bit confused and popped inside just to get glares from the staff. We waited another ten minutes or so before heading to the front only to discover there was a waitlist which we not informed of on either occasion and since we didn't put our names on it we had been waiting for nothing. I explained what happened to the hostess who could not care less and said there's nothing to be done. Accordingly, we left and will never return. Although they may have great ramen according to other reviews they clearly don't know how to run a business. Why a business would put there waitlist in the back of the restaurant is beyond me, but as we saw multiple parties wait around confused or leave it's certainly costing them business which is fine by me.

RXD-a9HAvOqPa77BhvalkQ.text: I really wish I could give this review a higher rating but I left here only feeling satisfactory. The food is 5/5, don't be afraid to try the takoyaki! I'm not big on octopus, and I loved this appetizer. The Miso and Nishikawa ramen is amazing as always.   Please note my mom has come to this location 5+ times and has never had bad service. I've only been to the one in chandler and probably won't come back to this location. This location is small. There's about 11 spots to sit at. We came in with a party of 9 for my sisters 16th birthday and were told previously on the phone it's first come first serve bases and we were okay with that.  The girl who helped us was named Allison and was not very friendly and needs to learn a lot. We asked if we could sit down at two tables waiting for the rest of our party, they said it was okay but we would also have to wait for a couple next to us to get up so our party can fit. That was fine.  Our server (Allison) did not offer us waters in the duration that we were waiting. Someone else asked us how are food was tasting and checked up on us. We had to periodically ask for more silverware for the kids and was not even offered the little trainer ones if they even had them. There was even a group next to us who had the same issue but just finally got upset and got up to ask her. Easy solution to this is 'eye contact' coming from someone who's a server/bartender and deals with 11+ tables a day. Granted they were fully sat and quite busy but that shouldn't prevent good service.  She dropped off our checks without saying a word and no one greeted us bye on our way out.  If this were a secret shopper report she would have failed.   We obviously were celebrating something and that was not acknowledged at all. Our server Allison needs a lesson in empathy/compassion or the service industry isn't for her.

Cf_HeYH5dTBu36g1yK_OaA.text: This is the most authentic ramen you will find in all of Phoenix, hands down. After traveling to Japan several times, I recently moved to Phoenix. Eager to find something that resembled the ramen made with such passion like back in Japan, I found myself continuously losing hope with every so called "ramen shop" in town I tried. Trying what feels like every ramen shop around, from bland broth (Tampopo) to ramen with toppings with ADHD (SoSoba) my hope dried out like the dry pork bellies that caused it to become void.  Until....two days ago.  This gem, this diamond, this glorious almighty savior of ramen in Phoenix had opened to ignite that light of hope in me.  With the first sip of the Tonkotsu ramen broth, I closed my eyes and was instantly transported back to the streets of Shibuya. The complex flavors danced around in my mouth like a melodic symphony. I wanted to run to the chef and on my knees bow down to him for providing me this gift, this taste, this feeling, of being right there, back in Japan enjoying ramen made with passion and love.  After I came back down from this ecstasy, I moved on to the noodle; incredible! (I was told by the waiter were made in house. (Again passion!)) Then on to the pork belly; succulent! Then to my ultimate test, the egg...ace! Oh man, those flavors, the layers intertwining with one another, the complexity! I was not let down!  If I ever want to make a quick trip back to Japan for some ramen, I'll start my car and drive 12 minutes down the road.  Gochisosama Deshita!!!!!!!!

z8SOtu-r6fD087cRFcVHHg.text: Great food, service and atmosphere! Love this place food is amazing, hidden gem!! We will be back.

3g85hUYU6Pg00c-M2l9cVQ.text: Great Ramen, friendly staffs. The tonkusu ramen is full of flavors!  Solid 5 stars! I would definitely come back again to try their miso ramen next time.

I'm so happy they have a location in Phoenix! I will definitely be a regular!

VKuNR1JQMOdvyjYcLK9qJw.text: I ordered the Nishikawa Black Ramen and it was a bit salty. Egg was overcooked and overall tasted a little too greasy for my taste. Ls5Wpx-u_nK4XGXX6vbIUA.text: My family and I were really excited to try Nishikawa but were extremely disappointed. We came in around 5:30 on a Sunday night and were sat a table for 2, despite having 3 people instead of being seated at a table for 4 because the "dinner rush" was coming -- this would've been fine except the waitress was rude in saying so, and there was a couple that had just been seated in a corner booth suited for 4?  My aunt ordered the vegetarian ramen, which was extremely salty and the "vegetables" that came with it were sprouts, onions and corn. We asked to sub one of the "vegetables" for spinach and was told it wouldn't be possible. The saving grace of the tonkatsu ramen was that the spice level was actually decently spicy. Although the ramen came with straight noodles and a hard boiled egg -- no traditional ramen shop would ever. Additionally, to add maybe 2 tablespoons of plain corn (not buttered, salted or anything) was $1.50!  Even the customer service was poor. We watched a family of 5 come in, and the waitress that greeted us told them "We don't have any tables right now." and then walked away -- didn't ask if they wanted to wait for a table or anything.   Would maybe give them another chance, and would definitely make sure to have the curved noodles and a soft boiled egg.

yUX9Cy6CYD6azv0ZCESZRA.text: Nishikawa Ramen!! Gosh, what can I say Im just really love having these diverse cultural dives popping out here in the Valley. I AM truly a huge fan of this Ramen restaurant especially, when they marinate the broth for more than 20 hrs and they make their noodles from scratch fresh every morning- i mean you know this place is top notch! I love my Ramen, Seafood and asian food and Its because im born/raised in Oahu, Honolulu where we have so much of these places back home. Ive been too a few here in the Valley and it was "One time deal only" but, I come here once a week usually for "Take out!" but, this past week was my first time I actually had some time to bring a co-worker and we ate in! Shes a vegetarian so I was surprised they had a Veggie Ramen, sorry im all about having chasiu in my Ramen - my favorite dish is the Nishikawa Black - all my favorite ingredients and just every single bite and slurp of their pork broth Its so divine!! For our appetizer I suggested we have their "Takoyaki" now, if you are not a seafood person - stick with the gyozas or something else because you wont acquire the taste! But, their Takoyaki is one of the BEST Takoyaki I had ever tasted before in my entire life! Not even back home in Honolulu - just cannot compare at all! I even asked the waitress what is in the ball and she kept saying the dough/steaming! Whatever it was " literally melts in your mouth" and pieces of the octopus - gosh, totally worth it for us seafood lover! The funny part is because it came out steaming hot and they put the furikake (seaweed) and flakes of the dry skin octopus on it was moving... Hahaha! My friend was like "what da???" Lol- i told her "Hello, Its steaming hot so the octopus flakes is just shrinking I grabbed some of it and ate it... Lol! So she feels comfortable and know Its Okay, too eat! Cracked up laughing told her "Eh, good thing no more the eyes!" Lol- eat that too! Lol Im Happy to advertise this place and Happy they make one of the best Ramen place in the Valley! I do however agree with some of the Yelp reviews on here that their young kids in here sometimes give bad customer service! - just smile girls, breathe, and relax!! Lol

r28vC_lYxF0kPkGHvMZvlg.text: I've only had ramen a few times before so I'm definitely not a connoisseur but I thought this was pretty good. We got there about 12:30pm and were seated right away. nCCSJPvDdpfNzbrV44uH9g.text: Good ramen requires excellent broth and noodles.  I'd give the broth a solid 4 stars.   Not too oily, savory, and great aroma.  The noodles however were just ok.  I like a wavy noodle and these are thin and straight.  Couldn't determine if they are made in house or not.  Toppings were a little basic.  Just scallion, seaweed, pork belly, and an egg.  I found the seaweed to be too chewy and lacking its own flavor.  Overall, none of the ingredients have distinct flavors of their own.  Decent enough bowl of ramen.  Wouldn't wait in line for a bowl.

D5SJYWHVF4VySMzHYZvqsQ.text: Not much variety. Granted I've only been twice but the first time broth was too salty and another time it was too bland. Both times I got the one with black noodles with the garlic sauce since it was the description that appealed to me the most... But it was nothing to write home about. Sadly, it's the only ramen place in Phoenix. I wish they would open up more places

_FXd83yzejjE3LuwoZo8Rg.text: Since the moment this place opened up I've been wanting to try it & yesterday was finally the day! I am SO happy I did because I just had the best ramen I've ever had. It's close to my house so this will be a blessing and a curse.   QUALITY- The food was absolutely spectacular. I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen with soft boiled egg and my boyfriend ordered a medium special curry ramen with hard boiled egg. He didn't like his that much since it was salty, but I absolutely loved mine! I however LOVE spicy food, so if you aren't a spicy person I wouldn't recommend ordering it. When I finished my bowl I was genuinely sad because it was so good I didn't want it to finish. Definitely a 10/10 for me.     SERVICE- Please keep in mind that it is a small joint with limited seating for about 30 people with a small bar/hightop area that faces the kitchen. We were lucky to have gotten the last open table there but we noticed it was a good mix of "eat-and-go" people and "take-my-time-and-enjoy" people. The server was a sweetheart and even warned me that the soup was spicy but I assured her I love spicy food and she was glad to take my order! We didn't wait long for our food even though they were busy which was great.   PRICE- I'm not an expert in pricing for ramen but I thought it was a good price for what I received. Like I said this is close to my house to I'll definitely be back again!

Service is fast and the place is clean. More importantly is the ramen. It is delicious and currently our  #1 next to Tampopo in Tempe.
